awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Intra-annual Dynamics in the Gut Microbiota of Migratory Shorebirds
awd_abstract_narration:
Gut microbiota plays a vital role in organism health through facilitating nutrient uptake, detoxification and interactions with the immune system. Whereas the mammalian microbiota is predominantly shaped by underlying genetics, factors affecting the avian gut microbiota remain largely unknown. Migratory shorebirds are sensitive to environmental change as a result of their use of geographically wide-spread habitats throughout their annual cycle. The local environment thus has the potential to alter avian gut microbiota. This research will investigate environmental factors influencing gut microbiota of migratory shorebirds as their long-distance movement and intercontinental migration annually expose them to a wide range of microorganisms and potential pathogens. The overarching objective of this study is to evaluate the importance of the local environment in determining gut microbiota composition in migratory shorebirds, by assessing presence and causes of intra-annual variation in gut microbiota in relation to breeding, staging and wintering environments. Migratory shorebirds have the potential to act as disease vectors that spread pathogens over long distances, and investigation of gut microbiota diversity and function is an essential first step towards identifying current and future disease threats to both avian and human populations. 

The overall objective of this research will be addressed by testing three hypotheses related to different aspects of environment-gut microbiota interactions: site characteristics, duration of stay, and interactions among migratory populations. The researchers predict that the local environment largely determines gut microbial composition, and that within this environment the effect of latitude and flock composition on gut microbiota composition will be detectable. Shorebird gut microbial composition will be analyzed from fecal samples collected from key shorebird staging and wintering sites throughout the Western Hemisphere. Bacterial communities will be sequenced using genetic techniques and microbial communities will be analyzed by using advanced bioinformatics and a Bayesian statistical framework. This research combines the fields of migration ecology, microbiology and computational biology.

por.por_cntn:
Summary. – The goal of our project was to evaluate the importance of local environment in determining gut microbiota composition in migratory shorebirds, by assessing presence and causes of intra-annual variation in gut microbiota in relation to breeding, staging and non-breeding environments. Migratory shorebirds are sensitive to environmental change as a result of their long-distance movements and use of geographically widespread habitats throughout their annual cycle. Therefore, local environments have the potential to alter avian gut microbiota. To address our overall objective, we tested hypotheses related to different aspects of environment-gut microbiota interactions: site characteristics, duration of stay, pathogen prevalence and interactions among migratory populations. To address these hypotheses, we analyzed bacterial communities in fecal samples collected from shorebirds throughout the Western Hemisphere. In total, we analyzed bacterial communities from 1755 fecal samples from 15 different species of shorebirds captured at sites in from Canada, the US (AK, DE and WA), Peru and Argentina. We sequenced the bacterial 16S rRNA genes present in all fecal samples using the Illumina MiSeq sequencing platform, and identified indicator bacterial genera and Operational Taxonomic Units for different sites and species. We found that local environment was the best predictor of the shorebird gut bacterial community composition, but that at a smaller geographical scale, species identity is also important.

Intellectual Merit. – Gut microbiota play a key role in health due to interactions with the immune system and nutrient uptake. Despite research interest in the composition and function of gut microbiota in mammals and domestic poultry, there is a critical gap in our knowledge on diversity and function of the avian gut microbiota, especially in wild birds. Our project made several key contributions to the fields of Ornithology and Microbiology. First, we generated a large set of sequence data identifying bacterial community composition of a wide range of species within the shorebird lineage, collected over a wide geographical range. All sequence data will be made publically available, allowing them to be used for future meta-analyses and to explore new questions, such as intra- and interspecific comparisons in gut microbiota composition within and outside shorebirds. Second, we are in the process of screening a subset of our samples for prevalence of 10 known avian pathogens, including Campylobacter sp., Salmonella sp., and Clostridium sp., which will allow us to identify geographical pathogen hotspots and species at risk. 

Broader Impacts. – The broader impacts of our study were three-fold. First, investigating the role of local environment in gut microbiota-health interactions, as well as identifying geographic patterns in pathogen prevalence informed us on potential risks for shorebird species. All our four focal species are listed as declining according to the IUCN Red List of threatened species, and the Red Knot (Calidris canutus) was recently listed as “threatened” under the Endangered Species Act. Second, we developed several domestic and international collaborations. For sample collection and analyses we have been collaborating closely with the Arctic Shorebird Demographics Network (AK & Canada), the Delaware Division of Fish and Wildlife (DE), the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WA), the University of Florida, Gainesville (FL), CORBIDI (Peru) and CENPAT-CONICET (Argentina). National and international collaborations were successful, and have resulted in new connections and contacts that will facilitate field collaborations on future projects. Last, our project has provided training for one female graduate student, one female undergraduate student and two technicians in field sampling, molecular techniques and bioinformatics. Research products included four conference presentations and an invited symposium on shorebird ecology and conservation. All research was conducted under federal and state permits for wildlife research, and research protocols were approved by institutional animal care and use committees.
